human: Nowadays, technology has been developing significantly, impacting many aspects of our life. While there is belief that technology advances means a lost in traditional cultures, I would argue that although the affect of technology on culture is undeniable, it has also contributed to the preservation of traditonal culture.Thanks to modern technology, our life has been improved with many gadgets. The invention of mobile phone and internet has changed our traditional ways of communicating as well as working, it has also been much less labourous than in the pass with the assistance of electrical machineries. However, these newfangled practices has replaced many old traditional ones. For instance, factories equipped with new and highly-productive system has replaced old handmade products, the exchange of letters among friends is so hard to be seen as we have had emails and social network instead, new video games has superseded the old-physical ones. Many old traditionally cultural things have long gone as a result of modern technology.However, despite the drawback mentioned above, technology has also made some contributions to the maintenance and study of traditional cultures in some ways. Internet has aided to assess the young generations to the cultural identity of many nations from all around the world. With the help of advanced methods, many art masterpiece has been well restorated and well preserved. Modern devices also assist the scientists to study the ancient societies much more deeply, hence discovering more cultural traces.To give a brief conclusion, Modern technogy has impacted the traditional cultures in both negative and positive ways.
llm: The rapid advancement of technology has brought about significant changes to various aspects of our lives, including the way we preserve and interact with traditional cultures. While some argue that the inevitable march of technology will lead to the loss of traditional cultures, I partially agree but also believe that technology can play a role in preserving and promoting these cultures.On the one hand, it is undeniable that many traditional cultural practices and artifacts have been lost or altered as a result of modern technology. The widespread use of digital media has led to a decline in traditional forms of storytelling, music, and art. For instance, the rise of e-books has reduced the demand for traditional printing techniques, and the ease of digital communication has made handwritten letters a relic of the past. Moreover, the homogenization of global culture, facilitated by the internet and social media, has resulted in the loss of unique cultural identities.On the other hand, despite these drawbacks, technology has also made significant contributions to the maintenance and study of traditional cultures. Digital platforms have enabled the preservation and dissemination of cultural heritage, allowing people to access and learn about traditional cultures that may have been previously inaccessible. For example, online archives and museums have made it possible to digitize and showcase traditional artifacts, while social media has provided a platform for cultural exchange and education. Additionally, technology has facilitated the study of traditional cultures through data analysis and visualization, enabling researchers to gain new insights into cultural trends and patterns.In conclusion, while technology has undoubtedly led to the loss of some traditional cultural practices, I do not believe that it is inevitable that traditional cultures will be lost entirely. Instead, I believe that technology can be a powerful tool in preserving and promoting traditional cultures, as long as we harness its potential in a way that complements and enhances our cultural heritage.

question: Universities should accept equal numbers of male and female students to study in every subject. To what extent do you agree or disagree?Ê
human: There is a view that universities and colleges should equally enroll male and female students in numbers in each faculty. Personally, I do not agree the viewpoint, because many different characters exist between male and female students.On one hand, boys and girls have the diversity in psychological modes and individuality. Most of male students tend to use their left brain to think and act, and they are more rational and logical than girls in many cases. For instance, there are more male scientists and engineers in comparison with females around the world. Many boys are interested in science and technology, while a number of girls like to learn literature, education and arts. Besides, girls are more likely to prefer some jobs related to emotion and communication, such as teacher, singer and interpreter. This means that girls differ from boys in mind and behaviour to a large extent, and they both have better ability in the specific aspect.Furthermore, it can have a negative affect on these students to require them to choose a subject in equal proportion of gender, and that does not conform to students' personality traits and mental development. For example, a girl, who is interested in literature, is arranged into an engineering department, but she is unlikely to focus on her subject, and this also can block the girl's future development and career prospect.On the other hand, universities should encourage more girls to choose science subjects and more boys to study the humanities, and this could avoid imbalance of gender in some subjects. It would affect students' mental health to study in the environment of single gender.In conclusion, it is necessary for universities to respect the individual choice of subject due to the diversity of boys and girls, and we ca not forcedly put the same numbers of males and females into every subject.
llm: The topic of university admissions has been a longstanding debate, with some arguing that institutions should accept equal numbers of male and female students in every subject. While I understand the sentiment behind this argument, I disagree with the notion that universities should adopt a strict 50/50 ratio in every faculty.On one hand, it is undeniable that boys and girls often exhibit different interests and aptitudes when it comes to academic subjects. Many boys tend to gravitate towards science and technology fields, such as engineering and physics, while girls are often drawn to literature, education, and arts. This natural inclination should be respected, and universities should not force students into fields they are not passionate about. By allowing students to pursue their genuine interests, universities can foster a more motivated and engaged student body.On the other hand, it is also important for universities to encourage students to venture out of their comfort zones and explore diverse fields of study. For instance, universities should actively promote science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields to female students, who are often underrepresented in these areas. Similarly, male students should be encouraged to consider humanities and social sciences, which can provide a well-rounded education and valuable skills. By promoting diversity in course selection, universities can help break down stereotypes and provide students with a broader range of skills and knowledge.In conclusion, while I believe that universities should strive for gender equality in admissions, I do not think that a strict 50/50 ratio is necessary or desirable. Instead, universities should focus on providing a supportive and inclusive environment that allows students to pursue their genuine interests, while also encouraging them to explore diverse fields of study. By adopting this approach, universities can foster a more dynamic and well-rounded student body.

question: Many people believe that media coverage of celebrities is having a negative effect on children. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this opinion?
human: Celebrities, for example movie stars, are usually seen on media living a luxury life or having a new girlfriend, etc. It is human nature that people, especially youngsters, are attracted to the celebrities they favour, and that is why the media prefer to cover as much news of the celebrities as possible. But I tend to think that this is a worrying tread which has negative impact on children.The first impression of the celebrities seems that they are rich while not having to work hard. This gives children the idea that it is not necessary to study hard at school for a better career and earning a living. Further more, they will not value other people's hard work and take everything for granted.Meanwhile, not all celebrities are role models. It is not uncommon to see on the media that some of them are committing to crimes or misbehaving such as being addicted to drugs or alcohols, having messy sex lives. Worse still, without proper parenting, children may perceive that this is the cool life people are supposed to be living.Of course, some celebrities, e.g. writers, passionate entrepreneurs are good examples to children for they share fascinating stories or how to pursue their goal by doing something that has a meaning to them and may change the world.In conclusion, media should shift its focus from covering celebrities to elsewhere. Meanwhile, children's access to the celebrities news on the media should be restricted and they should study only from the celebrities who can act positively.
llm: The media's extensive coverage of celebrities has become a topic of concern for many, particularly when it comes to its impact on children. In my opinion, I strongly agree that the constant media coverage of celebrities is having a negative effect on young minds.Celebrities, such as movie stars, are often portrayed in the media as living luxurious lives, with lavish spending and high-profile relationships. However, this perceived ease and extravagance can be misleading. Many children may assume that these celebrities achieved their success effortlessly, without putting in the hard work and dedication required to reach their current status. This can create a distorted view of reality, leading children to believe that hard work and education are not necessary to achieve a better career and earning a living. As a result, some may develop a lack of motivation and poor work ethic, which can ultimately hinder their future prospects.Moreover, not all celebrities are positive role models. Some may engage in scandalous behavior, such as substance abuse or reckless spending, which can be particularly damaging to impressionable young minds. The media's constant coverage of these negative behaviors can normalize them in the eyes of children, leading to a desensitization of their harmful effects.Overall, I believe that the media's coverage of celebrities can have a profoundly negative impact on children. By portraying a lifestyle that is often unrealistic and unattainable, the media can create unhealthy expectations and a lack of motivation in young people.

question: "Prevention is better than cure". Out of a country's health budget, a large proportion should be diverted from treatment to spending on health education and preventative measures. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
human: In today's world, the concept of the welfare state requires governments to provide sustainable healthcare and health education to their citizens. I completely agree with the idea that governments should devote a greater portion of their health budgets to health education and means for precautions.The first reason why education and preventative measures should receive a greater budget is the potential improvements in health system. I believe that decreasing the number of patients in the health system can lead hospitals and healthcare centers to be managed effectively which will result in better treatments for current patients. Therefore, society should be educated and became aware of health issues so that the potential precautions on the way of illnesses can be taken instead of trying to provide treatment for the increasing number of patients.The second reason why governments should allocate more budget on prevention from illness and providing health education is the welfare of the society. In my opinion, there is nothing more important than health in a human's life and the happiness and welfare come with health. Therefore, a government's role should be providing means that lead its citizens to learn how to prevent from potential illness that can cause misery in people's lives. For example, the marketing campaign of Ministry of Health in Turkey which aimed smoking problem among the youth increased the well-being of those who quit smoking and adapted a better lifestyle after the campaign.In conclusion, a greater proportion of the budget should be allotted to education and prevention issues in comparison with treatment due to achieve more effective health system and greater level of well-being.
llm: In today's world, the concept of the welfare state requires governments to provide sustainable healthcare and health education to their citizens. This concept has led to a debate on how healthcare budgets should be allocated, with some arguing that a larger portion should be diverted from treatment to health education and preventative measures. In my opinion, I strongly agree with this statement, as prevention is indeed better than cure.First and foremost, preventative measures are more cost-effective than treatment. Chronic diseases such as heart disease, diabetes, and obesity are on the rise, and treating these conditions is extremely costly. By investing in health education and preventative measures, governments can reduce the incidence of these diseases, thereby reducing the financial burden on the healthcare system. Moreover, preventative measures can also improve the overall quality of life of citizens, enabling them to lead healthier and more productive lives.Another argument in favor of allocating a larger portion of the budget to health education and preventative measures is that it empowers citizens to take control of their own health. By educating citizens on healthy habits, nutrition, and disease prevention, governments can reduce the reliance on healthcare services. This, in turn, can reduce the pressure on healthcare systems, allowing them to focus on more critical cases.In conclusion, a greater proportion of the budget should be allotted to education and prevention issues in comparison with treatment. By doing so, governments can reduce healthcare costs, improve the quality of life of citizens, and empower them to take control of their own health. This approach is not only economically viable but also morally responsible, as it prioritizes the well-being of citizens and promotes a healthier society.

question: Fatherhood ought to be emphasized as much as motherhood. The idea that women are solely responsible for deciding whether or not to have babies leads on to the idea that they are also responsible for bringing the children up. To what extent do you agree or disagree?
human: In today's world, having and raising children can be a very difficult task for families, the smallest component of the society. While mother's role is essential in a child's life, I completely agree with the idea that fatherhood is a as vital part of a healty parantage as much as motherhood.The first reason why the father's role should be equal to the mother's role is the nature of parantage. In my view, the role models within a family play a significant role in the development of the child's characteristics. For example, in a traditional Turkish family, while a mother has a sincere and thoughtful approach to the child, a father role must be present as authoritarian and conversative to raise a well-behaved child. The second reason why I believe that fatherood is as important as motherhood is the dynamics of the relationships today. In my opinion, we are living in a society that puts a significant importance to gender equality in every aspect of the life, including relationships. For instance, a family formed by a woman with a housewife role who looks after the home and takes care of children and a man who brings money home can not be seen anymore in today's society. Instead, all of the couple duties are performed equally and interchangeably by individuals. Therefore, I believe that having and raising children should not be different than any other daily activity.In conclusion, fatherhood should be as present as motherhood in a child's life starting from the the birth due to providing appropriate parenthood and having healthy family relationships.
llm: In today's world, having and raising children can be a very difficult task for families. The traditional notion that women are solely responsible for deciding whether or not to have babies often leads to the assumption that they are also solely responsible for bringing up the children. However, I completely agree with the idea that fatherhood is as vital a part of healthy parenthood as motherhood.While a mother's role is essential in a child's life, providing emotional support and nurturing care, a father's role is equally crucial. Fathers bring a unique set of skills and perspectives that are essential for a child's development. Research has shown that children who have involved and loving fathers tend to have better social, emotional, and cognitive development. Moreover, fathers can provide a distinct male role model, which is particularly important for boys, helping them develop a strong sense of identity and masculinity.In my view, the role models within a family play a significant role in the development of the child. Children learn by observing and imitating the behavior of their parents, and having two positive role models can provide a more comprehensive and balanced upbringing. A father's involvement can also help to alleviate some of the pressures on mothers, allowing them to share the responsibilities of childcare and create a more harmonious family environment.Therefore, I strongly believe that fatherhood should be emphasized as much as motherhood. By recognizing the importance of fathers in childcare, we can work towards creating a more balanced and equitable society, where both parents are valued and supported in their roles. This can have a positive impact on families and society as a whole, leading to better outcomes for children and more sustainable family relationships.

question: It is important that children should study hard at school. time spent playing sport is time wasted. to what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
human: Some people believe that studying hard is essential part for children, otherwise others people think that playing sport is waste of time. In my point of view, both of studying hard and playing sports are part of life to children. On the other hand, studying hard will give children a better future. Studying hard gives children with a plenty of knowledge and skills for their future. Naturally, children will be growing up and looking for their job. For instance, children who always studying hard and getting high achievement, it will be easy to pass qualification for work and they are more likely to find great work at multinational company. If they working at multinational company as the result is they can earn higher salary. The message is when you always studying harder than others you will get best results.At the same time, playing sports will give good effects on children. There are many popular sports among children such as football, basketball, and volleyball. Also, there are many benefit when children doing sport. Firstly, children who always playing sport like football, they will be active as a person and learn to become team-player. It will be good for children, because indirectly they will learn how to socialize each other as a team. That will make children getting lots of friends, so they can contribute positively to community. Secondly, playing sport makes children getting healthy and become children's well-being. In conclusion, both studying hard at school and playing sports can improve children's future.
llm: The statement that "it is important that children should study hard at school, time spent playing sport is time wasted" is a highly debatable topic. In my opinion, I disagree with this statement. Both studying hard and playing sports are essential parts of a child's life, and it is not accurate to label one as more important than the other.On one hand, studying hard is undoubtedly crucial for a child's academic success and future prospects. It provides them with a wealth of knowledge and skills that are necessary to excel in their chosen careers. A good education lays the foundation for a child's future, and it is essential for their personal and professional growth. However, if children are only focused on studying, they may miss out on other essential aspects of development.On the other hand, playing sports is equally important for a child's physical and mental well-being. Engaging in sports activities helps children develop important life skills such as teamwork, discipline, and communication. Moreover, playing sports is an excellent way for children to stay healthy and active, which is vital for their overall development. Regular exercise has been shown to improve concentration, boost mood, and reduce stress levels, all of which are beneficial for a child's academic performance.In conclusion, I strongly disagree with the statement that time spent playing sports is time wasted. Both studying hard and playing sports are vital components of a child's life, and it is essential to strike a balance between the two. By doing so, children can reap the benefits of a good education while also developing important life skills and maintaining their physical and mental health.
